I made a mostly 3D printed car. It is very light especially with just the little quadcopter batteries so it goes pretty fast. It is really just intended for indoors.

The video shows a bit more detail of the design.

I have only uploaded the steering part for now. Some of the parts might be small by a factor of 1000 (sometimes happens when exporting from blender -I have not figured out why).

The rest is still a work in progress.
The rods are 3mm brass and all are friction fit. You may need to drill out the holes or use glue depending on your printer.

The finished car
<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/67Su8OhVuLs" ></iframe>

title: AEG Freeezer compartment hinge and clip

description.text:
This is a repair section for the AEG ‘Fridge Freezer Shelf Trim With Flap Catch’ which has a UK model number of AEGUK61436 Various listings describe it as fitting models AGN81800F0, EUG2243AOW, AGN71200F0, A92200GNM0, AGN71800S0, AGN71800F0, AGN71200F0. I have uploaded both left and right handed designs.

The full bracket is 360mm in length, too long for most printers so this just replaces the hinge and catch at the front. You will need to cut the existing shelf bracket 255mm from the rear end and re use this part. It works OK in PLA but I have used E3D Edge (PET) in Dover White. I suggest a high infill percentage as the brackets are prone to breakage or set the number of top and bottom layers to get the front arms to be solid. I have successfully printed them with layer thickness of 0.35 or 0.15mm.

author: gt6k

title: Maker Select Plus / Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus Y Idler

description.text: I wasn't happy with the stock Y idler bracket on my Monoprice Select Maker Plus, so I created a new one. This uses the stock two mounting holes, but also needs an additional hole drilled. M3 nuts fit securely into the bracket. The stock hardware for the idler itself can be used for installation on this bracket.

comments.text:
Found 2 designs of the idler holder for the Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus. I liked this one better because of it's professional looking design.
But - the upper 2 eyes for the shaft screw have rather deep recesses for the screw head and nut.
This causes the remaining wall to become very thing. Just holding it between 2 fingers caused the upper part of the eye to break off immediately.
Question: could you modify the design in a way such that the wall on both sides is kept in full thickness? The screw head, round, recess is not really required. The nut holding walls could be added from the outside. I'd even make the walls a bit thicker, there is plenty of space.
This would require the use of a longer shaft screw, not a big problem as they are easy to get. Keeping the stock screw doesn't allow for enough wall thickness on both side, causing the structure to become to weak.
comments.author: mkaz58

comments.text: I'm sorry you're having issues with the strength of this part. I have over 150 hours of use on mine with no problems, so I find it a bit strange that you are having it break in your fingers. Are you printing at 100% infill with at least 2 walls?
comments.author: mkaz58

comments.text:
Thanks a lot! Great work.
I'll print today and provide feedback.
comments.author: cambunch

comments.text: Thank you for this!  What should I print this out of? ABS or PLA?  Also, what layer height do you recommend?  Infill?
comments.author: deeek777

comments.text: PLA should be sufficient (I personally use PETG). I would recommend 100% infill to get the best strength as it is a small part that shouldn't use too much filament.
comments.author: deeek777

author: cambunch

print_settings.Notes:: Printed in MakerGeeks Crystal series Red PLA

description.text:
My daughter, her friends and myself have having a blast with @271828's Pull String Helicopter. But I had to see if I could take it up a notch. I have a bunch of 2204/2205 brushless motors and ESC's laying around so figured a powered version would be fun.

Since 271828 was kind enough to share his solidpart files I was able to open the hub in Onshape and remove most of it, then add a 5mm hole in the center and an opening sized to fit the nut on this particular motor (it's NOT sized to fit a standard 5mm nut as the only ones I had on hand had large flanges on them which made them too large to fit inside while maintaining the integrity of the hub.)

The Onshape project is here if anyone wants to modify this further:
https://cad.onshape.com/documents/120c05cbd1daa0960651817d/w/0259438f83c0697b2e8aff1b/e/799261b008764e4709b70116

I'm also working on a modification of the handle to mount the 220x motor on top and hold the electronics.

Right now I'm just using this with a 12a "simon series" emax esc because it the first small ESC I grabbed out of my parts stash. But I suspect an ESC with better active braking would work much better since it should allow for a quicker release of the helicopter. I'm just using a servo tester to control the motor, but when I get a bit of time want to switch to an arduino so you can just push a button and it will spin up then stop automatically. I tried it on both 2s and 3s lipos and 3s did seem to get a bit more altitude but not a lot.

Kind of thinking about making the handle able to hold to 18650 cells for power...but worried they can't put out enough current for this. Need to run some tests first.

Still working on modifying the handle - 18650's won't cut it...this thing is drawing 22amps on a 3s lipo. And this is just using a servo tester. Once I wire in a micro to make it pushbutton should get better launches since it can stop the motor quicker without the time it takes me to turn the knob:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7OTZb2jl0rY

just a treasure chest i made goofing around in 3d studio.

Modeled implicitly (the shape is completely described with an equation) via Mathematica using basic geometries and Boolean Operations.  
The main shape is created with a Boolean Addition of a Mobius Strip to a Sphere.

description.header: The model code used in Mathematica
Base code courtesy of Professor Mark Ganter
description.text:
(Boolean Join)
join[f, g] := Min[f, g]
(Boolean Cut)
cut[f, g] := Max[f, -g] (Translations)
transX [f, s] := f /. x -> (x - s)
transY [f, s] := f /. y -> (y - s)
transZ[f, s] := f /. z -> (z - s) (Rotate)
rotateRZ[f, a] := f /. {x -> xCos[a] + ySin[a], y -> -xSin[a] + yCos[a]}
rotateZ[f, a] := rotateRZ[f, d2R[a]] (Declaring a Primitive Geometry: Sphere)
sphere[rad_] := x^2 + y^2 + z^2 - rad^2 (Declaring a Primitive Geometry: Mobius strip - http://www.wolframalpha.com/input/?i=mobius+strip+Cartesian+equation)
mobius[a_] := -a^2 y - 2 a x z + x^2 y - 2 x^2 z + y^3 - 2 y^2 z +
y z^2 (Creating a geometry: muckabout3)
muckabout3 = cut[sphere[2.75], mobius[3]] (Creating a geometry: trasn2rotatma3)
rotatemuckabout3 = rotateZ[muckabout3, 180]
transrotatema3 = transY[rotatemuckabout3, -0.5]
trans2rotatema3 = transX[transrotatema3, 0.5] (Creating a geometry: trans2rotatma13)
transrotatema13 = transY[muckabout3, 0.5]
trans2rotatema13 = transX[transrotatema13, -0.5] (Joining two geometries together)
joinedmuckabout3 = join[trans2rotatema13, trans2rotatema3] (Creating a geometry: transrttma32)
muckabout32 = cut[sphere[6], mobius[3]]
rotatemuckabout32 = rotateZ[muckabout32, 180]
transrotatema32 = transX[rotatemuckabout32, 3]
transrtransma32 = transY[transrotatema32, 1]
transrttma32 = transZ[transrtransma32, -2.75] (Joining two geometries together)
joinmuck3s = join[joinedmuckabout3, transrttma32] (plot the model for a preview)
plt = ContourPlot3D[joinmuck3s == 0, {x, -10, 10}, {y, -10, 10}, {z, -10, 10} (export your model as an STL file)
Export["ISMmodel1.stl", plt, "STL"]

title: SciFi Terrain Tiles (4"/10cm)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Updated 1720EST 26AUG2017 - Changed the size and spacing of the interface between the patterned tops (also thickened in the Z space) and added the OpenLock bases - end result - they can be mixed and matched using an existing open source game tile system.

4" x 4" (100mm x 100mm-ish) 3D printer tile designed to represent samples of random terrain for the surface of massive space stations, notably for use with Sci-Fi based miniature games. I mashed these together in Simplify3D as my initial attempt at SciFi tiles. Then I sized the tiles to be around 3mm thick to maintain some texture for inking and dry brushing with the intent to make the tiles as level as possible for use with X-Wing basing.

These tiles are a combination of following two sets:

My original tile sets.

OpenForge 2.0 Plain OpenLOCK Base (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1910972) by devonjones (https://www.thingiverse.com/devonjones/about) is licensed under the Creative Commons - Attribution - Share Alike license. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/

If you make a 3D trench run for the X-Wings miniatures game out of these before I do I'd love to see your setup.

Should be fully compaitble with https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2458305, which are much closer to the look and feel of that universe.

Designed in Visio, output as a PNG then converted into an STL by the "Convert Image to 3D" function in Simplify 3D.

If you are inclined to be more than a taker and a consumer, pay forward by contributing to this site, as so many others have before you, or perform a random act of kindness, or donate to a good cause when the opportunity next arises. If you liked it enough to download it I'd appreciate a LIKE, it helps get the word out and spread these designs around. That is all.

title: Enclosure for Raspberry Pi 3 + TFT3.5'' + DAC PCM5102K - Squeezebox
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Hi !

This is an enclosure for my squeezebox project.
I need to install the following equipment inside:

  • Raspberry Pi 3 : http://www.gearbest.com/raspberry-pi/pp_488334.html?lkid=10899003
  • A waveshare (or clone) 3.5'' TFT for Raspberry: https://fr.aliexpress.com/item/Free-shipping-LCD-module-Pi-TFT-3-5-inch-320-480-Touchscreen-Display-Module-TFT-for/32587995145.html
  • A DAC PCM5102K:
    https://fr.aliexpress.com/item/PCM5102-DAC-Decoder-I2S-Player-Assembled-Board-32Bit-384K-Beyond-ES9023-PCM1794-compatible-Raspberry-Pi/32678406932.html

I use max2play as software, but any Linux variant for the Pi should be ok.

You can improve my design using the fusion 360 project:
http://a360.co/2s5AMXU

Known issues and release notes:

Initial Version (Fusion 360 v27)

1- the screen slot is a very tight fit with my printer. You may want to print it upscaled by 101% or so.
2 - For some reason the holes for the RCA barrel are too high by about 1mm.
3 -The recess in the cover is too small for the pins sticking out of the screen.
4 - the tabs on the cover are much too fragile.
5 - The hole for the jack barrell of the RasPi is too small.
6 - The opening for the HDMI slot could be enlarged too.

First Revision (Fusion 360 v29)

  • Correction of issues 2, 3, 4, 5, 6 of the previous version.
    1 - The tabs of the cover are still very fragile. Any advices welcome.

Please let me know if you have tested my design and what you think about it !

Creality CR10

-Tensor inferior (x2).
-Tornillos para madera 3.5 x 25mm o 3.5 x 30mm (x6).

Montando éstos tesores se le quita un poco de altura en Z, porque molesta las varillas, pero yo lo he dejado así porque no suelo hacer piezas altas. Si alguien quiere que meta suplemento que lo comente y hago un stl nuevo con la altura de más que se me diga.

Los tensores superiores tienen ya unos suportes para el canto inferior, de todos modos hay que poner soportes para que termine de salir la pieza.

Para el montaje yo recomiendo:

  1. Meter dos tuercas en la parte central de la varilla roscada.
  2. Introducir la varilla por los tensores superior e inferior, quedando cada uno en un extremo de la varilla, si no entra bien taladrar con una broca de 8mm.
  3. Colocar tuerca en la parte de abajo del tensor inferior.
  4. Bajar tuerca a la parte de arriba del tensor superior y apretar.
  5. Colocar tensor superior en la anet.
  6. Subir tuerca a la parte de abajo del tensor superior sin apretar, "solo lo justo sino moveremos la estructura de la impresora".
  7. Meter tuerca por la parte superior y apretar.
  8. Colocar tornillo y tuerca métrica 3 original en el tensor superior.
  9. Meter 3 tornillos para madera de 3.5mm de ancho por 25mm o 30mm de largo, si entran muy apretados taladrar los tensores inferiores con la broca necesaria.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dCXcJ0fIqq0

title: SC8UU replacement for IGUS Drylin RJ4JP-01-08 (LM8UU)

description.text:
I wanted to upgrade my LM8UU to IGUS Drylin.
First attempt was to just swap LM8UU in the existing aluminium SC8UU by IGUS Drylin RJ4JP-01-08.
Result was a lot of bearing clearance.
According to datasheet, the IGUS drylin bearings need to go to a percision machined hole setting a certain preload.

I looked for some printable SC8UU replacement with possible good preloading / clamping.
Found nothing applying force on all circumference. I didn't just want to clamp the IGUS drylins in one direction.
Here is what I came up with.

Already in place for the X - Axis on my Anet A8; no play in X Axis any more.
Can be adjusted by mounting screws.
The four in the picture are to go to the Y Axis.

Needs 4 screws M4x25, a nut M4 and a IGUS Drylin RJ4JP-01-08 each.

Can be combined with printed bearings also:
https://www.thingiverse.com/make:427051

Designed with onshape; source link:
https://cad.onshape.com/document-redirect.html?d=/documents/265813617707d1c56544b1b5/w/78a7bb831d00a2f2c1d3a28e

comments.text:
I just had similar issue on y axis a week ago. Either stick slip and jittery movement or even stepper getting hot. For me, disassembling and cleaning the bushes sorted it. I had a small amount of oil on the rods from old ball bearings, which over time got into the igus bearings...
There should not be any lubricant in this setup. Igus bearings have self contained lubricant.
Worked for me - hth
comments.author: Jori

comments.text: I'm having an issue and I hope you can help me out. If I tighten these down enough to stop shifting in the y-carriage the bushing bind and the stepper can't move it. Of course if I loosen it up enough to move the carriage it shifts around from the torque.
comments.author: naviathan

comments.text: How did these work with the alignment? I installed my drylins in the aluminum housings and I had soo much resistance from misalignment that I had to switch them back...
comments.author: Toasterbacon

comments.text:
Alignment was no issue for me.
I kept moving everything back and forth while tightening first the screws on the fixed side, then the ones on the opened side. With these, you can adjust play and amount of friction to your needs.
I meanwhile installed the four printed holders replacing the aluminium ones on my Y axis. Took some tweaking with screw force, but runs smooth by now.

title: Zcash Cryptocurrency Coin
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
As I was looking for a Zcash Cryptocurrency coin similar to Bitcoin etc, I found nothing on Thingiverse.

I drew this out, by downloading the .SVG artwork from https://z.cash/ converted it to .DXF and imported it into www.onshape.com to trace and extrude.

The coin is 45mm in diameter, 4.8mm thick (high)

To print in two colours, the bottom part (back part) is 2.4mm and the top part is 2.4mm as in the images shown.

I printed it at 0.2mm layer height, so on Layer 13 (before it starts to print) change filament colour.

Xixchia are a class one demon. found through out the lower planes and in between. they feed off any refuse they find.if encountered in groups of two to ten they have been known to attack living things. they feed by pressing their underside against their prey and absorbing its flesh straight into it. although it does technically eat, no one has ever found Xixchia scat. Xixchia do not need a mate, after a few months the Xixchia will begin to swell over a period of a few weeks until it can no longer move. it will stay like this until disturbed by a living victum, then the Xixchia will explode violently, shower it's prey in of thousands of tiny newborn Xixchia. as i study these creatures i might update this entry.

title: travel trailer red battery connector protector

description.text:
I put these over the loop connectors that normally attach to the positive leads of the battery of my RV, then bungee down all the loose wires. These prevent the bare connectors from the loose red wires from contacting with the trailer hitch they are lashed to when the battery is not present (like when I'm putting the camper into or taking it out of the storage lot).

To use these, put the wire into the slot and then pull the connector up inside the protector. Lash or secure the wires just behind the cinched-up protector so it can't jiggle its way off.

For larger battery leads you can scale up the entire mesh in all dimensions at once. Don't scale Y without Z or the 45-degree roof will exceed 45 and require support materials.

title: 05-10 Ford Mustang A/C Blend door Actuator Gear Replacement

description.text:
If you have ever tried to turn on your cars A/C or heater and heard a clicking noise, more often then not it means one of your actuators have failed. Usually one or more of the gears in the actuator fail and instead of moving to open and close blend doors, the actuator motor spins without registering a position change from the arm decoder located within the unit.

This is the center gear used inside an A/C door blend actuator in 05-10 Ford Mustangs. Drop in replacement gear saves you the money in having to order a whole new actuator. The plan is to model all the gears within the actuator so hopefully someone can repair any broken part within the gear train.

Short install walk through here:

\http://imgur.com/gallery/6jjZU

author: Alex18881

description.text: 5X5 TIES

This is an alien I designed in Blender for use in science fiction role-playing games.

Senovian star polyps are grown inside Senovian star-worms and periodically deposited en-masse onto planets where carbon-based life is detected. Upon landing, they will work to gather whatever biomass they can find and convert it into a new star-worm. Though rare, star polyp invasions can wreak havoc on human colonies that aren't sufficiently prepared. Even a single polyp is more than a match for anything less than serious military hardware.

I recommend printing the model as is with supports.

UPDATE July 4, 2017: Added STLs for 40mm pipe

Rotor-Racing has been using the I-Laps infra-red (IR) timing system ever since we began running drone races. The system uses 3 or more IR sensors mounted on or near the start/finish gate to detect the unique ID that is transmitted from an IR transponder mounted on each drone.

This sensor bar uses cheap, readily available PVC tubing to create a sensor array that compensates for drones that cross the line at a high bank angle. The minimum recommended number of sensors is 3, but we run 5 for standard BFPVRA/FAI gates (3 in the vertical section, 1 each in the 45 degree sections).

The main bar is constructed from ~3m of tubing, with a 135deg elbow for the bend at the top and a 135deg tee for the kick at the bottom. We use a standard weighted flag stand to hold ours up but a ground spike works equally well. The design includes spacers for padding out the flag stand pin to fit the vertical tubing.

The aperture template provides a means to line up and mark out the sensor recess before cutting it out. This ensures the smallest hole possible that allows the sensor to be inserted, whilst maximising rigidity of the pole and resilience against drone collisions.

The wedges are hot-clued to the back of the sensor bar and provide a flat surface on which to mount the sensors (we use velcro for this), keeping them well protected inside the tube without compromising their field of view.

The whole model is parametrically designed in OpenSCAD so I can produce parts for any size tubing just by tweaking a few numbers. I've uploaded STLs for 32mm and 36mm tubing, but if you need other sizes then leave a comment with inner/outer dimensions and I'll create another variation.

description.text: Hello! A few weeks ago, a local parent came to me and asked if I could make a drumstick prosthetic for her son, whom had a hand with no fingers and almost no thumb. I said I would be happy to help, and so here it is! The Autodesk Inventor files are included so that you may modify the files to your needs.

Notes:

Print each piece separately, to make sure the fit is correct. It is recommended to print out of either ABS, nGen, or XT. The Inventor Files are included if any modifications need to be made. Happy Printing!

Assembly

Make sure to sand/remove all sharp edges, bore out any holes, and tap the clam shell holes to M3. clean the surfaces before adhering Velcro and foam good luck!

You will need:
Self Adhering Velcro
6mm medical foam
1/4 - 20 Threaded rod (At least 4 in long)
2 X 1/4 - 20 nuts
3 X M5 nuts and 25mm long M5 bolts
1 x drum stick
10 x m3 x 20mm bolts (Stainless Steel)
Print:
1 x cuff
2 x m5 thumb knobs
1 x 1/4 - 20 knob
3 x Spring
1 x Hand Shell
1 x Palm Shell
1 x Joint
1 x DrumStick holder

print_settings.Notes:: Be sure to look at your slicer and pause at the appropriate place to insert your pennies - I can't teach you specifically how to do this as different firmware handles things differently. If you are a shameful geek like me, you might manually edit the gcode to split the print into two files so you can print the bottom, walk away, then print the top whenever you are ready. You take risks doing this, however, as you will need to understand what certain codes do or you risk things like having endless spaghetti spit out of your hot end. (Has this happened to me? Maybe, maybe not.)

title: Wheel fidget spinner - complete with tire

description.text:
An Excellent Basic Spinner

I have two kids on the Autism spectrum who are exceedingly high-functioning but also tend to fidget quite a bit. Contrary to what you might have been reading in the news, fidgeting is not necessarily a bad thing! Yes, if you have a classroom of kids conspicuously spinning their fidgets, comparing them, doing tricks and the like, then yes, they are problematic. For kids with ADHD, autism, or those who just learn differently, a spinner can be a discrete, quiet means of staying on task by occupying their hands. Incorporated into an IEP, they can be exceedingly helpful.

After designing a couple of minimalistic spinners for my two kids on the spectrum, my other two kids thought it would be nice to have spinners as well (for home use, of course). This is one I designed with the input of my youngest son.

I'm particularly proud of the two-component construction for the wheel and tire. When printed in flexible filament, the tire should be relatively easy to put on the wheel, yet will "snap" into place and not come off too easily.

Trap those pennies!

I love designing "impossible" things for my 3D printer. One thing that truly baffles those unfamiliar with FDM printers is the idea of "trapping" objects inside a print. My spinners all make use of this concept.

Instead of using comparatively expensive bearings, my spinners all use trapped pennies. Pennies are, well, cheap! They also weigh a decent amount, allowing you to use quite a few while still keeping costs down.

This particular print makes use of 21 pennies - 7 sections of 3 pennies each. It results in an exceedingly heavy spinner resulting in some great spin times, if you invest in the right kind of bearing or just do a good job cleaning a cheap one.

Make use of your printer's pause function if you have one. I'm actually a fan of manually splitting my gcode files - something I wouldn't advise unless you know the commands fairly well or you might end up ruining your print.

I would recommend examining your slicer to find out where to pause the print - just before it bridges over the penny cavities. I can't tell you the precise layer because that'll depend on what layer height you choose along with whether or not you use a raft.

Penny problems!

One disadvantage of pennies is imbalance. Pennies have changed composition quite a bit over the years. As such, their weight varies considerably between the "olden years" and those "modern" pennies.

You might consider collecting all pennies from one year. Alternatively, pair pennies from the same year on opposing sides. The better you pair them, the more balanced your spinner will be.

Tight fit!

I have my printer tuned in fairly well. The tolerance on the center bearing is only 0.1mm for the radius (0.2mm for the diameter). I have to actually tap my bearings in using a flat block of wood and a hammer but once they are in, they tend not to come out! The same is true for the pennies.

Given the variance of printers I can't guarantee your printer will yield the same results as mine. Your pennies may be too tight. Mine are extremely snug. Your bearing might be too loose. Mine is tight. All I can say is you might need to play with your scaling factors should things not work the way you expect.

That said, with some effort, this spinner can give that special someone you know a little bit of fun. My kids like theirs, even if it is just to play in their spare time.

Where's that letter?

Well, that letter was in the original design for the caps. I'm not including it here in case you want to use Meshmixer or the like to "emboss" some other letter.

DISCLAIMER

You know the drill. You are printing something on your printer. You are responsible for what you print. Don't give spinners to kids, adults or pets who have a tendency to pull apart things and place them in your mouth. Several components of a spinner would be rather nasty to your health should one try to ingest them. Don't throw a spinner at someone - it hurts.

Use common sense. Be responsible. Have fun!

Printer:

BobsCNC RP9 v2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

25% or more

Notes:

This should be a simple print. There is a fair amount of bridging but PLA should handle it well. As long as you have good adhesion, things should turn out nicely.

Be sure to look at your slicer and pause at the appropriate place to insert your pennies - I can't teach you specifically how to do this as different firmware handles things differently. If you are a shameful geek like me, you might manually edit the gcode to split the print into two files so you can print the bottom, walk away, then print the top whenever you are ready. You take risks doing this, however, as you will need to understand what certain codes do or you risk things like having endless spaghetti spit out of your hot end. (Has this happened to me? Maybe, maybe not.)

Nothing fancy here. I used Autodesk Fusion 360 which is fast becoming my favorite tool for most design work. It's truly easy to use once you get the hang of it and it can be extremely powerful. Also, while technically not free, for a hobbyist under certain circumstances, you can use it for free. Please be sure to review Autodesk's license to ensure you fit in this category. Again, you are responsible for yourself: PAY UP for a license if you don't fit the mold for the free license!

description.text:
After changing the Filament I was frustrate. That was not so easy. The best way is to remove the small Extruder Fan. After remove the Fan the Extruder Stepper-Motor is unmounted. That is not so nice, the new Filament is in, the Nozzle is Hot, and you need four Hands to fix the Fan / head sink / Extruder Stepper-Motor at the right position. I have tested it with loose only one Screw, it was just the same but different. Now I searched and printed from others a similar Holder, I was dissatisfied. The Screws holds are not fitting and the Fan and Broke the Holder. I Have make this small helping Thing new, with extra space and easy to use. Only thing you need to do is to take the head sink and to rasp the Hole at one side a little bigger to see the Filament hole. (See Photo)

If you have a problem or an improvement for this thing please let me now it.

Nach den versuch das Filament zu Tauschen hat es mich genervt das ich dafür den halben Druckkopf zerlegen muss. Der einfachste weg ist den kleinen Extruder Lüfter zu entfernen. Das ist nicht gerade super, Das neue Filament ist drin, die Düse ist heiß und du brauchst 4 Hände um den Lüfter / Kühlkörper / Extruder Schrittmotor wieder richtig zu befestigen. Danach habe ich das mal versucht in dem ich nur eine Schraube entfernt habe , das gleiche Spiel nur anders. Nun mal auf die Suche ob andere das Problem schon zufriedenstellend gelöst haben und habe mir ein paar ausgedruckt und war enttäuscht. Die Schraubenlöcher waren zu klein und der Lüfter hat den Halter zerbrochen. Also habe ich das kleine Hilfsteil, mit extra Platz, selbst neu entworfen. Das einzigste was man machen muss ist es am Kühlkörperloch eine Ecke wegfeilen damit man das Filament Loch der Düse sieht. (Siehe Foto)

Schreibt wenn es noch was zu verbessern gibt.

Update for the Extruder Fan Holder.
Here the Holder in new Design and with an Upper Part. This is for more air to cool the Extruder Stepper Motor and für Holding the Fan for the Filament Change.
Lock at the Picture.

Update vom Extruder
Hier der Halter im neuen Design und mit einen oberen Teil. Das obere Teil ist für die bessere Kühlung für den Schrittmotor des Extruders und zum halten des Lüfters beim Filament Wechsel.

But that was the only solution for me to remove the Fan without using any tool to easy and quick change the filament. description.text:
An exercise in fun

I've been designing spinners for my kids. It's been a fun experience and I enjoy exercising my creative side. After seeing the kids play with theirs for a while, I was bit with the bug - I wanted one!

Initially, I designed a simple 4-nut spinner in translucent red filament (one of my favorite spools). Then, for my wife's and my anniversary, she bought me some FoxSmart bronze filament!

The idea of a bronze spinner immediately popped into my head. Then, I thought to myself, "How can I logically combine the bronze with a hand spinner?"

I knew what I must do...

Steampunk

In the right context, I really enjoy steampunk style. That mix of Victorian or sometimes Art Nouveau with elements of the industrial/steam age is a rather cool intersection of fantasy. It romanticizes the style of key points in history along with a "what if?" analysis of where "steam" energy might have taken us.

The style has been generalized to include clockwork mechanisms with chunky gears and the like. I think this fits more into the latter category. While I would assume some steam power could really spin one of these rather fast, I truly wouldn't recommend it on a PLA or other plastic creation. Not only could it melt your cool creation, it's just kinda not smart.

Aw, nuts.

Before I got into trapped penny spinners, I thought the idea of a nut spinner might be a good one. Nuts, while not as cheap as pennies, are far cheaper than bearings, especially if you get plain old zinc-coated nuts.

The nuts, in this case, are about 17.2mm in diameter, edge to edge. (That is, the diameter of the circle that inscribes the nut.) They give some heft without costing very much. The neat thing is they kind of fit with the whole steampunk theme. My nuts, according to my records, are 7/16" GR5 hex nuts from Home Depot and cost $0.17 each.

An advantage of nuts over pennies is that it is generally much easier to create a balanced spinner using nuts rather than pennies due to the difference in makeup of the pennies over the years.

Tight fit!

I have my printer tuned in fairly well. The tolerance on the center bearing is only 0.1mm for the radius (0.2mm for the diameter). I have to actually tap my bearings in using a flat block of wood and a hammer but once they are in, they tend not to come out!

Given the variance of printers I can't guarantee your printer will yield the same results as mine. Your bearing might be too loose. Mine is snug. All I can say is you might need to play with your scaling factors should things not work the way you expect. In fact, one of my nuts was just a little bit tight, causing the spinner to crack. I used some spare filament and a rotary tool to "weld" it shut, but it did result in a little bit of a scar. Nonetheless, I like the overall outcome.

DISCLAIMER

You know the drill. You are printing something on your printer. You are responsible for what you print. Don't give spinners to kids, adults or pets who have a tendency to pull apart things and place them in your mouth. Several components of a spinner would be rather nasty to your health should one try to ingest them. Don't throw a spinner at someone - it hurts.

Use common sense. Be responsible. Have fun!

Printer:

BobsCNC RP9 v2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

30% or more

Notes:

If you plan on using a metal-fill filament (and I would recommend it for the best effect), you will likely need a higher infill and more top layers to ensure minimal pillowing. I used 4 top layers instead of the usual 3 to help minimize pillowing, but I still think I could have upped my infill a bit.

For the caps, I had a happy accident clearing out my nozzle of bronze filament with some cyan scrap. When I pulled the filament out, it was coated with some bronze PLA and my mind immediately went to turquoise rock with flakes of copper and quartz. As such, that is what determined the two-tone combination of the two filaments.

In addition, I used a rotary tool with some bronze filament to try and get the mottling effect on the edge of one of my caps. I wasn't entirely pleased with the results so I decided not to do it with the other.

As far as the spinner itself, I did no post-printing finishing aside from welding a crack caused by putting in one of the nuts. I did not polish sand or otherwise finish the spinner's surface.
Nothing fancy here. I just used Fusion 360, did some simple flourish designs for the embossing, and went with it!

description.text:
For the past two years I have been designing and redesigning this print head to be extremely accurate as well as versatile and modular. Originally I designed this to fit on my Geeetech i3 pro b (metal parts) but now that I've got the design nailed I modified it to be used with any Prusa (or similar) printer.

Why this design?
This design is one of the lightest direct drive print heads out there without sacrificing usability; here are some examples:

  • This print head is designed around the idea of being modular. Whether you are using this with the Geeetech i3 pro b (with metal parts) or you're printing the adapter plate for a genuine Prusa, it only takes 2 screws to remove the print head for cleaning or replacing.
  • The V6 can reach temps of up to 295c or even 420c with a simple thermocouple upgrade!
  • Equally impressive, the snappy Titan extruder can handle just about any plastic you throw at it (but it works much better if you feed the plastic into the top instead of practicing your throwing arm). I've successfully printed with PLA, ABS, PET-G, TPU, and even Ninjaflex!
  • Last but not least... the speed! Like I said earlier, this design is one of the lightest direct drive systems out there. Combine that with the nozzle being super close to the X rails (to lesson any effects of wobble) and you're looking at some great speeds! (I usually run with my perimeters at 70mm/s and my infill at 150mm/s)

Anyone looking to make this will need both "Fan_Mount" files as well as the "Fan_Duct_v1" - Also, these print head files require two square m4 nuts. If you don't plan on removing the print head excessively (I do because I'm working on multiple print heads) then you can print the "Plastic_Nut" file twice and glue them into the slots instead of actual metal ones.

Geeetech Printer (metal parts)

Anyone looking to make this for their Geeetech i3 pro b (metal parts) will need to download one of the print head files that has "Metal_Carriage" in the name. (There is a standard version as well as one for a BL Touch and another for an induction sensor)

Any other Prusa

Anyone looking to make this for any other prusa i3 will need to print out the "Carriage.stl" in order to attach the print head to your printer. Also, make sure to print out the appropriate print head file (it must have "Plastic_Carriage" in the name) These print heads also come in 3 variants:

  1. Standard
  2. BLTouch
  3. induction

https://youtu.be/zvbm6Siv9Fo

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2 or better

Infill:

50% or more

Notes:

I suggest PET-G or at least ABS - Don't use PLA if you want it to last any length of time (PLA is known to warp over time and you need the tolerances to stay tight)

Required Hardware
  • E3D Titan (and included hardware) https://goo.gl/2vbNfF
  • E3D V6 (i used a clone to get a full-medal hotend) https://goo.gl/85u9SY
  • 50mm blower fan https://goo.gl/CS8xxv
  • M4 square nuts https://goo.gl/coQzM2
  • M4 (20mm) bolts https://goo.gl/7hLwU5
  • Short body NEMA 17 https://goo.gl/Sdbicv
  • M3 (16mm) bolts (for fan mount to motor) https://goo.gl/r8Uroa
  • M4 (8mm) bolts (if you don't have Geeetech) https://goo.gl/QFeVFQ
Assembly

Due to the unorthodox way this print head works, there is an unorthodox way to assemble it.

  1. First, you're going to want to assemble the E3D Titan. Don't screw it to the motor, just put the titan together (and put the V6 in it's position). At this point you can screw down the corner that pinches the V6 in the extruder.
  2. Next you will want to get the head mount ready. Clean off any support material and insert the M4 nuts into their respective places. Secure them with a dab of superglue (make sure to not get any glue in the threads) Also, keep in mind that you can print the M4 nuts if you want to be cheap.
  3. Now that you have the head mount prepped and you have the Titan and V6 together, go ahead and slide the Titan into the head mount. Make sure that you have it the correct way around (the big hole in the Titan should line up with the big hole in the head mount) and then go ahead and tighten the gear onto the shaft of the NEMA 17 stepper.
  4. As you may have guessed, it is now time to fit the motor to the rest of the unit. I have found the easiest way to do this is to lay the head mount down, big hole up. Then use your right hand to hold the tensioner arm in place ( make sure the tensioner spring and nut are in place). With your left hand, lower the motor shaft into the hole and through the tensioner arm. Great! Now before you bump it and have to go through this step again, go ahead and flip the entire assembly motor down (carefully) and insert the respective screws into their proper locations.
  5. Almost done! All you have left is to unscrew the top, left screw on the back of the motor, as well as the bottom, right screw. Replace those screws with M3 x 16mm screws but not before threading the fan mounts onto them.
  6. Now all that is left to do is screw the fan onto the fan mounts (just let the M4 bolts cut threads into the plastic of the fan mounts) and add a little dab of hot-snot to the fan's ducting in order to ensure it doesn't fly off 45 hours into a 46 hour print and wreck the entire thing (no sense in having a great printer if it attempts to sabotage itself)

!!!CONGRATS!!!

You now have a great print head for your printer that is not only light and fast, but that can also tackle ninjaflex as well as extreme temps! If that isn't enough keep in mind it's also designed to be modular so why not put a plug in your wiring harness and make even more print heads?! (Personally I have a CNC head that I swap out to make circuit boards)

comments.text: Nice Work but can you also prepare a version witch normal hexagon nut's or without nut's only screwing direct in to the holes without printed nut's?
comments.author: freakezoid

comments.text: The design uses plastic nut inserts because the original design just had holes for the threads to dig into but over time this started to fail from the screwing and unscrewing action. The printed nuts are so you can keep an extra set just in case one gets stripped. As for using square nuts instead of hexagonal: It is easier to strip the plastic capturing the nut if it is hexagonal. Therefore using square nuts allows for more tension. As an added benefit, people with printers that aren't completely accurate will be able to get a hobby knife in the square holes to tidy up the sides much more easily than a hexagonal hole. Also, sorry for the slow reply- I haven't had time to think about printing for a few months now due to college.

comments.text: I looked over your design - definitely looks compact and light. It reminds me of the ever so popular Mk8 extruder but functionally looks almost identical to the E3D Aero. I haven't had a chance to play around with one of those yet but once i do you can be sure that'll be used in my next print head (I plan to be running on a hypercube by then). As for repeatably however, I feel my design has a much larger audience due to the 'off the shelf' components I've used - I'm sure yours could be a popular print head if you optimize for availability and generate a complete parts list for your viewers. Best of luck to you!
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: My aim was to make the best extruder using parts I had on hand  from old printers/scanners to save cost. Nothing left from the MK8 although it appears so because I have the heat sink and fan mounted in a similar way. I did it because it leads to a shorter hot end compared to the E3D. On the video you can see the heat sink/fan mounted horizontaly as an alternative. The motor too can be mounted on top or bottom or even the side (but here the Gravity center would be too far away). I desgined the mount that way for flexibility. My design predates the Aero but true is similar except mine allow an easier access to the hobbed gear. Easy to load the filament too, any kind, flexible of course. Now, that it works, I could make it popular by using off the shelf gears and motor. I don't do it so far because there are some unique design features  that I don't want to be copied by people making money from it. I dont care about "popularity", I care about making the best. Yet people can get inspiration from it.
comments.author: Inventech

comments.text:
Checked out yours... I can't even tell what you have going there. I think it's great you can hack stuff together like that, but what good is a mount like yours if we can't get the same parts (or have no desire to have one so ugly)? And your photobucket link? Holy bajeezus dude, please nobody click that link! What the heck has happened to photobucket (not your fault)? Have you ever heard of youtube? You should use it instead of photobucket. Then you can also post in on here like the photos. I did manage to download your video by right clicking the link and saving as. Looks like it works great. Not only is it fast because it's light, but looks like maybe you're also using a 32bit controller and it's doing the direction change smoothing? I can't think of the name of the firmware that does that - although I'm sure there's more than one, and for someone who can code, you can probably make any do it... although my lousy 8bit controller probably can not handle it.
I have no doubt you know what you're doing with regard to the project, but you need help on how to post things in a way lesser geeks like me can understand... for sure. ;-)

comments.text: If you want great detail in the forming you need to make a hole and leg the vacuum lines to each profile then use a pecker drill .010 and drill vent holes in the profile so that its a full pull on vacuum on the profile would use baby powered to release the mold or reverse the vacuum to blow off. The design is a good idea but that many holes in the base plate you lose vacuum valume in the draw on the profile. Thats why in the big compenies they use vacuum ports and pecker drill the profile for great detail of the mold.

author: 2ROBOTGUY

description.text:
My Aldi ladder always did a good job and still does.
Only the red rubber shoes are damaged and broken by the sun UV-rays after the years.

I designed new shoes and they fit perfect.
They are as stable than the original and nearly undestructable (TPU64D Filament!!!).

Attention:
This is my opinion and you have to take care on your own.
You have to use the shoes on your own risk!

I can't guarantee the quality of replacement parts you print.
If your print is not stable don't use them on your ladder.
Maybe use a hammer to test it, TPU wil not get damaged if printed well.
Don't use hard filament like PLA, ABS, PETG, Nylon etc. - the ladder will slip away!
Than duck-tape can be the better choice to repair your ladder or get a new one.

Only TPU will be like rubber and give your ladder a stable stand on the new shoes

Akimbo

TPU won't work with capton-tape or similar.

author: Lookasteve

description.text:
One in a series of magic circles. Comes with floor tiles that can use any OpenForge 2.0 base and separate stone circles that can be placed anywhere.

These are all designed to print upright. The detail on them is too small to pick up well if printing flat. Since the z-axis is generally smaller then the nozzle on most fdm printers, when you want tight detail, it's much easier if you put that detail on the z-axis.

This is apparently an astral chart which is used in astrology. You'll need to use google translate to read that link unless you read spanish.

The 2" diameter circles were designed to work as the arcane circle pieces for Frostgrave: Ulterior Motives.

For instructions on how to get started with OpenForge, take a look at our tutorials.

OpenForge is now a patron supported project. I use the resources that my patrons give me in order to get the resources to let me create more sophisticated tiles with a greater level of detail. Please, support me, and I’ll deliver an ongoing stream of awesome gaming terrain. You can find more about OpenForge and Masterwork Tools at our:

  • Online catalog and backer site
  • Website
  • Forums (Mostly we use facebook now)
  • Twitter
  • Facebook

UPDATE 6: (22-08-2017) I have found this link and code for anyone that has not yet bought a CR_10.
I believe this is the cheapest price you will ever find for this awesome printer.
https://www.gearbest.com/3d-printers-3d-printer-kits/pp_441281.html?wid=21
coupon:CR1083

UPDATE 5: (28-07-2017) I am in the process of making an enclosure for the CR-10, super easy to build and cheap to make (IKEA style way to put together).will have the same feet idea.

UPDATE 4: I have added a racketball version for Kevin Le hans who told me these are way cheaper to buy. He will print them and test them for us. (this design does not have the cr-10 text on it as some one complained for adding it)
keep us posted Kevin.

UPDATE 3: Big leg now added here (works the same as the existing little leg except is taller so you can fit the electronic box underneath the cr-10 printer)
After this I will make a sleek box to enclose the lot.
It will give you 190mm clear (when ball is fixed on it) under the printer.see my little sketch

UPDATE 02: If you do end up 3D printing it, I ask you post a photo of it in action here, thankyou.
I also changed the licence- so no copies and/or remixes.
If you don't like it as it is, make your own that does not look like mine.
I don't like my designs butchered.

ALSO, WHO WOULD LIKE TO HAVE THESE LEGS LONGER SO YOU CAN FIT THE THING THAT SITS ON THE SIDE WITH ALL THE ELECTRONICS UNDER THE 3D PRINTER?
Let me know and i will make it.
Then i have planned to make a very sleek enclosure to the whole lot that will look a million bucks instead of the flinstone enclosure i am beginning to see.

UPDATE 01: look at the images I have attached in case you do not know what squash balls are.

Hi there.
After discussing on our facebook page ways to dampen the vibration created on surfaces from the CR-10 i have come up with this. I had made a similar thing for my old 3D printer

simply fit on the bottom of the frame, add squash balls and thats it.
post pictures when completed.

BTW, if you are thinking of buying a CR-10....I give this advice.
Stop thinking and buy it!
You will not regret it.

no supports needed

title: Hario Skerton coffee grinder unit stand

description.text:
This is a simple stand or support for the grinder part of the Hario Skerton manual coffee grinder. Usually I take the grinder off the jar before storing it, but it has a bit of an awkward shape and poor balance to place it on a flat surface. This stand offers a stable support for the grinder part and keeps it from spilling ground coffee remains all over the place.

I designed the model to use a minimum of material, but this particular shape proves difficult to print in filaments that tend to warp. This (and the fact that it simply looks nice) is one of the reasons why the cylinder walls bulge outside, this counteracts the possible inwards warping that may occur, meaning that the print will still be usable even if your print settings are not optimal.

I give no guarantees about the correctness of the Japanese text, but since it was mostly copied from the text on the box, it shouldn't be total nonsense.

print_settings.Notes:: Happy printing and modding!

description.text:
I made this plate to mount a 60 mm fan over a 4 inch (101.6 mm) vent opening on the top of my enclosure, so I had no problem mounting the plate, as the fan bolts had nothing on the other side to bump against.

I ended up drilling the plate mounting holes a bit wider to fit some spare screws I had.

Although the fan holes are to spec for the 60 mm mount, the plate holes are just centered 7mm from both edges, so you may want to move them or make them bigger to meet your needs.

remixed_from.title: MobBob V2 - Smart Phone Controlled Robot

description.text:
This is a remix robot, in this case the app is Absolutelly Open Source.
Also, this arduino surce is more easiest than this original, because I'm developing a library that make more easy programming many positions with only 4 lines.
This library is based on inverse Kinematic.

The pack include
x1 tutorial in spanish.
x1 file in corel draw to print in 2D
x1 file in STL to print in 3D
x1 file in .aia to using in app inventor
x1 file in .apk to download in your smartphone.

This is Day 15 of my collection of printable equations. To see the whole collection, go to: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:227210 I'm continuing the series of polynomials today, with y = x^3 . Details:
  • units are in mm
  • Range(x) = -50 to 50
  • a = 1/2500
    • As always, I'm going to continue to post one equation per day until get bored or people lose interest. If there's a particular equation you'd like to see, leave a comment and I'll give it a shot.
All files can be printed without support. Photos shown were printed on a Replicator 2 and sliced using the standard setting on Makerware.

Due to popular demand on the facebook group, I have released this file for free.

In return, if you print this and like this model, please consider leaving a small tip by clicking here or the link below. It would help me out a lot. Cheers!

http://paypal.me/HenryQiu

If you printed one, be sure to share. your make, I'd love to see how it looks!

title: Dremel Flex Shaft Storage Rack (pegboard compatible) with extra tool storage

description.text:
This is a compact storage rack for the Dremel Flex Shaft attachment (available here: https://www.amazon.com/Dremel-225-01-Flex-Shaft-Attachment/dp/B0000302Y8/ ). It is compatible with pegboard (standard 1/4" holes with 1" spacing), but also includes holes for custom mounting solutions. It additionally features storage locations for a standard Dremel wrench, a few Dremel tools, and the unique chuck that comes with the Flex Shaft.

Instructions / notes:

  • Print out one "Dremel Flex Shaft Rack.stl". The rack is about 6" long. If it's two big for your printer, print out a "Dremel Flex Shaft Rack Right.stl" and a "Dremel Flex Shaft Rack Left.stl" and glue them together.

  • If you want to store Dremel tools on the rack you might need to glue some small magnets ( 3mm diameter by 1.5mm thickness ) into the horizontal holes to add some holding force.

  • If you want to pegboard mount the rack, print out two "Flex Shaft rack pegboard pin.stl" and glue them into any two of the 1/4" holes in the rack. Be careful to set the pins at the correct depth. For my pegboard the depth is about 10mm, leaving 5mm of pin sticking into
    the pegboard. Yours might be different. I recommend inserting a pin in your pegboard, marking a line for the depth, and then gluing to that line.

  • If you are not using a pegboard, you can mount it as you like using the holes provided. The rack features four 1/4" holes and two M4 holes spaced as follows:
    • The M4 holes are 50mm apart.
    • The center 1/4" holes are 1" apart.
    • The outer 1/4" holes are 5" apart.

  • You can design your own mounting bracket or use the simple right angle mounting bracket I've included ( "Simple angle bracket.stl" ). I've also included a bracket for mounting on an Ikea RÅSKOG Utility cart: http://www.ikea.com/us/en/catalog/products/20271892/ ( "Cart bracket.stl" ). It should also work on any 0.875" diameter shaft.

This is fully customizable universal card box.
You can adjust deck size, add custom text, choose any Google Font to engrave text, add logo, divide box with spacers and much more!
This is really what I was needed as board gamer but haven't, so I decided to make my own.
Next version will have additional parameters to add text on side faces and lid, dividers and more.
Fill free to make any feature requests and fixes.

description.header: How to make your own design
description.text:
1. Measure you deck, add some extra space to be able to eject deck easily
  2. Launch Customizer
  3. Enter parameters according to your preferences
  4. Choose box Logo (it's better to have black&white picture)
  5. Navigate to Stencil-o-Matic factory and upload your image
  6. Make needed adjustments and copy generated data to corresponding field
  7. This is it!

title: E-Wing x2 / x1 Holder (X-Wing Miniatures) for Stanley Organizer
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Latest Update: August 10, 2017. See Below for more

I use the Stanley 25-Compartment Organizers for my X-Wing Miniatures collection, and have tried many solutions for maximizing space and keeping the models safe. I reviewed most of the similar designs on Thingiverse, but there were none that had everything I wanted. So I started to design my own series, and based on my collection (I own at least one of almost everything, including Epic).

My design goals:

  • Maximize Space
  • Attractive Presentation
  • Include the pilot cards
  • Include the movement dials whenever possible

So, here is my initial design for the E-Wing. There are 2 different designs, one for 2x E-Wings (one flush top with sunken text, and one sunken top with raised text). The other is for one E-Wing, and will also hold the base and peg. Either design will hold the appropriate number of pilot cards (2x for 1 E-Wing, 4x for 2x E-Wings). This is the first time I have tried including the Base & Peg. I might work up a single E-Wing without the Base & Pegs. No room for the movement dials here.

This would be a great opportunity for dual-extrusion (but I don't have dual-extrusion yet. If there are requests, I can probably put up another version ready for dual-extrusion, instead of a cut-out design.

This will fit the Stanley 25 Compartment Organizer (https://amzn.com/B00005QWYF) or the Harbor Freight 20 Compartment version (https://www.harborfreight.com/tool-storage/part-storage/19-bin-portable-parts-storage-case-93928.html).

As I complete and post more of this collection, I will link them here as well.

  • A-Wing: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2397806
  • B-Wing: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2477298
  • E-Wing: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2404410
  • K-Wing: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2397829
  • Sabine's TIE Fighter: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2397957
  • T-65 X-Wing: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2397667
  • T-70 X-Wing: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2397764
  • YT-1300: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2397827
  • YT-2400: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2397816
  • Movement Dial Holder (7x): https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2397958

Yes, I will be posting Empire and Scum as I get to them.

UPDATE: July 1, 2017: Most models now have a v3.1 design, with the top of the cup lowered by 3mm, which will allow the "nubs" on the top of the Stanley Organizer to close better. Also, to accomodate this, I changed the Text and Logos to Raised instead of Sunken.

UPDATE: August 10, 2017: B-Wing Added! I haven't had a lot of time recently, so new designs are slow to come, but I am working on them. I am re-doing the Y-Wing design (it was printed in a gold and in one of the pics). Also, for those looking for color differences in materials, the X-Wing, A-Wing, and double B-Wing cups were printed with SainSmart Red PLA. For the Single B-Wing, K-Wing, E-Wing, Attack Shuttle, YT-1300, YT-2400 and Sabine's TIE Fighter, I used the GP3D Red PLA. I must say that I much prefer the color and finish of the GP3D Red over the SainSmart Red.

UPDATE: February 6, 2018: Life has kept me away from designing, so I haven't been able to work on any new designs in a while. I still intend to finish out the Rebel fleet, and then move on to the Imperials and Scum, but time will tell. In the interim, check out 3D_Pressure's Designs. While 3D_Pressure and I differ on a few design ideas, he has continued on in the spirit of my designs, and I really like some of his creative ideas.

Note #2: I know the YT-2400 and YT-1300 designs are a little tight sometimes. Next time I do a set of revisions, I will open up the hollow for both ships a little bit.

author: Lord_Dworkin

description.text: Voronoi House Design

So this is a dice tower. Based on a yin yang. The two spirals are 33mm diameter, which allow my largest die(29.5 across corners) to fit inside when printed spiral vase with a 1mm volcano nozzle. The big spiral part was designed with SV in mind. The other two pieces can be done however. I sized it with an 8mm gap in the middle for some 8mm or 5/16 threaded rod. The part was optimized for the build volume of my big printer, 300mm square 400mm tall. Ridges on the underside of the tube promote tumbling. Pyramids on the outer wall of the tray mimic the wall of a craps table, but i rarely see a die hit them. The 33mm cone can be placed in the tray to better show off a yin yang shape, but the entrance of the opposite tower is also at the position of the opposite color dot. When viewed from above, it looks like a yin yang.

comments.text:
Thought about doing that, but its already 400mm tall single piece, which is the limit of my large printer.
And the opening is the correct proportion to form a proper yin yang(1/8 outer circle diameter).
Also multiple dice at once is the only situation i found during testing which can cause a jam in the tube.

description.text:
This is a remix/inspired design of the LED ring design made by Djkirkendall, but intended for use on the stock HE280 effector platform.

I switched the LED ring to a 60mm version so that it wouldn't get in the way of the stock cooling fans and added a passage for the wires inside one of the clips to keep the hot end looking tidy. I'm very happy with the brightness of the LED ring, especially considering how cheap they were! I got the LED rings on Amazon from the link bellow:

https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01C85PVEE/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o06_s00?ie=UTF8&th=1

I hope you all like this simple mod for the HE280 as much as I do!

title: Fin Gripper (Robotic/Prosthetic Hybrid) - Mark VI
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The Mark VI Fin Gripper - Black Ram Hand. This hand was designed to use the The Fin Ray Effect giving the wearer the ability to pick up soft or odd shaped items not able to be grasped by rigid claws or fingers.

Each Fin Grip finger must be printed with a flexible material (I have used Ninja Flex for this one). I am not able to print flexible filaments on my printer so I used 3D Hubs to order the parts. The filament should be between 60-80 Shore A hardness (85 Duro shown which was still a bit stiff).

The hand is mechanically wrist powered and requires that the wearer have enough palm to push against the device. It converts the rotation of the wrist into a linear sliding motion to activate the end gripper. When the wrist is bent down the slider pulls back, closing the hand. When the wrist is straightened the slider pushes forward and the hand opens.

As can be seen the fingers flex around the object and then hold the part. There is a 2 finger "pincer" version and a 3 finger "Tri-claw" version.

Print:

14 x Bolts

10 x Nuts

3 x Fingrips - Print in Flexible filament or resin (60-80 Duro - Shore A)

3 x Hinges

1 each of the remaining parts.

If the fit of the parts is tight, lightly sand back the parts with a file.

The Black Ram Hand was designed not to be a replacement for current prosthetic hands, but to be an assistive technology tool/platform for allowing someone to design and use their own specific manipulators for individual tasks specific to that person. This is in the same way that Robotic grippers and end-effectors are designed for a specific goal. The Black Ram Hand is designed to help those with missing fingers or conditions such as Dupuytren's Contracture.

description.text:
Most spinners are a bit to big for smaller hands, so I designed one a bit smaller for my grandson.

The balls are 5/8" McMaster Carr #96455k58 (https://www.mcmaster.com/#96455k58/=1888jgl). Use a heat gun or hair dryer to warm up the plastic and they should pop right in.

I designed the caps from scratch and like they way they fit. My printer is calibrated, and when the two pieces press together, the center diameter should be ~8mm (you have calipers, right?) and lock in place. If not, epoxy them.

author: Professorburnout

title: 3/4" threaded adapter for Straight Line boat ballast bags

description.text:
I have a wakeboard boat with a couple of standalone ballast bags, along with a generic pump that has a 3/4" male threaded fitting on the end ( see photos). As a present, my friend bought me a Straight Line ballast bag, but didn't know it required a whole different water pump to fill the bag. We were unable to find a place that sold adapters to go from my pump to his bag, so....3d printing to the rescue. This parts fits very well and does the job. I did have a bit of leaking filling the bag, but it could probably be solved by putting a bit of rubber on the end of the part. I'm uploading the part in the hopes that I can save somebody similar trouble.

I recommend printing this part with heat treated PLA so that it survives the summer heat. I used Proto Pasta. ABS might also work, but I've never used it since I don't have a heated bed.Print it with supports, 100% infill for added strength.

This is a 3d Benchy torture test spliced with a dancing Baby Groot

First of all: English is not my native language, sorry.

I have bought a car recently and the car dealer gave me a USB stick with the company name as a gift, I like the USB but I don't like the way it looks so I decided to open it, take its insides and design my own and customized USB stick.

So I took this design from nugner_77: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1377626 and redesigned it for my personal preferences and made it a little bit more universal.

The one I printed have the Rammstein and Fiat logo because it has Ramstein music and I use I ton my Fiat, the versions I have uploaded are more universal because not everyone listens to Rammstein and have a Fiat.

I would really appreciate seeing this printed from other people :D

Printer:

Prusa I3

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

10 - 100 %

Instructions

  1. Take one USB and open it, If your measurements are less than the one I have used, it will fit inside the USB case

  1. Print the case.stl files

  2. Putt the circuit inside one of the case parts (No matter one of them) put the other on top and use a soldering iron to fuse the two parts with the circuits inside

  3. Chose between the blank parts (That you can customize with Sketch UP or others 3D design programs) and print two of them. In the case of the aperture, science covers this have orientation so you should print the one that says “Aperture Cover (Pack). stl”

  4. To put case covers I recommend to use a hair dryer to heat a Little bit the pieces so they fit better on the case, but not too much because the covers become deformed and become unusable.

title: Vertex Connector for Truncated Icosahedron (soccer ball shape)

description.text:
This is similar to the "Platonic Solid Vertices", but independently developed. If you look at a soccer ball you'll notice that it's made of pentagons surrounded on each side by a hexagon. So every vertex has 2 entries point into a hexagon vertex and 1 points into a vertex on the pentagon. This is easier to see in person since the difference in angles is subtle.
I am using 1/8" wood dowels.
I found that it's best to print these 5 at a time. This is such a small part that it does not have very much time between layers. You could also change the time setting between layers in your printer settings, but just making multiple prints solves the issue.

This is a plastic replacement shell for a multimiter probe. I used an nail (check if resistance is not too big) that I solder a cable to and then insert inside a probe and welded it together using 3d pen. print_settings.Notes:: The curtain rod end cap does require minimal supports just to hold up the ball. I printed 8 without supports in the void space inside the ball without problem.

description.text:
If you go to almost any big box store shopping for curtain rods, the average cost per window is around $45. With this project, the average cost is < $5 per window. I also included a small end cap just in case you don't have enough room for the large sphere end cap. I used it for the window in my closet.

Items Required:

  • 3/4 PVC Pipe (I used schedule 40 PVC as it was the cheapest)
  • 1' PVC pipe cutter / hand saw
  • Rust-Oleum® Specialty Black Direct-to-Plastic Spray Paint
  • 220 grit sand paper
  • Acetone

PVC Prep & Paint

  1. Cut the pipe to length to match the desired length. I cut mine at 42 1/2'
  2. To ensure paint adheres to your pvc you will need to sand it using 220 grit sandpaper. Sand the PVC pipe until all manufacturer labels, bar codes, etc are no longer visible.
  3. Wipe the PVC pipe with a wet cloth to remove all of the dust generated from sanding the PVC pipe.
  4. Lightly wipe down the pipe with acetone. A little goes a long way
  5. Paint the PVC pipe. This particular paint is dry to the touch in 30 minutes BUT this paint does take a full week to cure.

title: Diffuser for LED light strip in Lulzbot 5mm channel slot

description.text:
The first stick-on LED light strip I hooked up required a 12V supply and it was too wide to fit in the channel slot. It was blinding bright and I cut it back on the far side so it didn't blast the PI camera. I found a 5mm wide by 90cm long USB powered strip that fits the slot and is just the right length but it also was too bright on the eyes so I printed a diffuser to soften the light and keep the light strip in the slot.

LED Light Strip $4: https://www.fasttech.com/p/6978101

I cut the USB wires and inserted an ON/OFF switch.
Switch: https://www.fasttech.com/p/1135000

The diffuser cad file I used is 350mm long and it took 3 of them. I printed them one at a time arranged corner to corner on the TAZ print bed and used a natural 910 Alloy Nylon filament that is translucent. I've included another file that is about 260mm long.

title: 3D Printed Single Coil Pulse Motor
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: As a single coil 3d printed pulse motor, it has very little torque, and is basically useless except for science fair projects and bragging rights, but it is fun to assemble, fine tune, and test. Video of prototype at http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=t2n7DDyfocE. Printed on a Replicator 2 using Makerware "standard" settings in PLA. Caveats: After winding my coil, it measured 24 ohms resistance. At 5Vdc, that equates to .208 amps. Measuring the operating temperature using an infrared temperature detector, the coil temperature was ambient (room temperature). Running the motor at higher voltages will result in higher currents and thus higher temperatures which could melt the spool structure. Mine runs fine at 3 to 6VDC, which results in a safe spool temperature for PLA.

Parts (aside from a 3d printer and filament): 1) Bearings, Duratrax 1/4" by 3'8" flanged, part number DTXC1433. 2) 30 gauge 200 ft. (Radio Shack part number 278-1345, red wire). 3) Coaxial power jack (Radio Shack part number 274-1583). 4) 5 Vdc 2 amp power supply (Radio Shack part number 273-1696) or equivalent. 5) Reed switch (Mouser part number 876-ORD2210V-2025). 6) 6 12mm diameter 3mm thick Neodymium magnets (I found mine at a local hardware store, but amazon.com has them at http://www.amazon.com/Neodymium-Magnets-12mm-inch-Disc/dp/B00CWGQ3XI/ref=sr_1_3?ie=UTF8&qid=1391296865&sr=8-3&keywords=12+by+3+mm+magnet). Assembly: If any interest, to follow.

description.text:
Garden Tags for MPSM: Small printers can print the sticks in two pieces. Lots of versions are supplied but just open the Openscad file, go to the bottom, and change the name to make your own. This auto scales to give the right size always for any length of string. There is a one-line and two-line version. If you want to just print the pointy sticks, comment out the garden tag.

I suggest to use ABS for the sticks, or they will soften and fold over in the sun. Tags seems fine in PLA.

Support for the snap together sticks is included; just peel it off. It is hard to get the sticks apart after they are together, but it can be carefully done. Try different colors for sticks and tags.

description.text: This is an enclosure I built for this sensor: https://home-assistant.io/blog/2015/10/11/measure-temperature-with-esp8266-and-report-to-mqtt/. It houses an ESP8266 board, a DHT22 sensor, and a battery https://www.adafruit.com/product/2011. The battery is probably unnecessary for most applications since WiFi is pretty thirsty and will drain it in a few days, but it was necessary for my application. The enclosure has standoffs for a Feather Huzzah, but I am pretty sure it will fit a Node MCU as well. There is a port on the side for the USB power supply. Whereas wanted to make this fairly low profile, I also left some room for extra wires and or sensors.
Rhino Assembled enclosure

I designed this to fit under the guide bar running through the extruder mount. It fits snug against the block so you don't have to unscrew any fans. The hole for the caliper is set to 9.5mm dia to accommodate my caliper, but you can simply adjust for your needs. Hope you enjoy, it has helped me get my bed level since the factory didn't set it well or it shifted in transit.

The standard OpenSCAD fonts work well for a simple extrusion 3D profile. But what if you want a different 3D profile, e.g., you want text that looks like it's been machined with a V-shaped bit, or text that is rounded in 3D?

This library includes the ASCII portions of the Hershey vector fonts, and draws text using whatever convex shape you specify. For instance, you can do rounded text via:

use <hershey.scad>;
drawHersheyFont("Hello, OpenSCAD!", font="cursive") sphere(r=2,$fn=16);

A call to drawHersheyFont() requires a child object that specifies what the drawing is done with. The drawing is done by putting the child object at the two endpoint of a lines and doing a hull() operation.

The following optional arguments are available:

halign="left"|"right"|"center": horizontal alignment
valign="top"|"baseline"|"center": vertical alignment
size=x: specify height of capital T
extraSpacing=x: add this extra spacing between letters (can be negative)
forceMinimumDistance=d: make sure that the distance (not necessarily horizontal) between successive glyphs is as close to d as reasonably possible; use this if you want to draw fat letters that overlap by the same amount, like here
minimumDistancePrecision=p: set the precision for the forceMinimumDistance option

There is also a function to measure text width: widthHersheyText(text, font=name), with optional size=x and extraSpacing=x parameters.

Unfortunately CGAL rendering is going to be very slow. The "Hello, OpenSCAD!" CGAL render took about three minutes.

Note the licensing on the Hershey library in the source code, which isn't fully compatible with Creative Commons -- but the restrictions are very, very slight.

author: chocboy

description.text:
Part cooling duct for FLsun Cube 3D printer.

Created from scratch this cooler mounts on the standard hotend cooling fan.
there are two versions of the STL, one for the default 40x10mm fan and another for anyone who has changed their fan to a 40x20mm.

You should not need any supports, the part creates its own.

Requirements:

Designed for FLSUN Cube printer with default hotend, x carriage and Z-probe.
50mm blower fan, Example: https://www.coolerguys.com/products/evercool-50x50x15mm-high-speed-blower-fan-ec5015hh12ea-b

Directions:

  • Current Design only takes into account that the hotend heatblock is pointed towards the front of the printer(heating element on the same side as the cooling fan. Later I will look into designing alternatives for the heatblock being in all positions.)
  • Take care to choose the correct STL:
    • 40x10mm fan is for the default hotend cooling fan.
    • 40x20mm fan is for anyone who has replaced the hotend cooling fan with a larger silent fan. Example: https://www.coolerguys.com/products/scythe-mini-kaze-ultra-40-x-20-mm-silent-mini-fan-sy124020l
  • Rotate in your slicer 180 deg in x (sorry too much effort to fix in modelling software)
  • (tested)Print in PLA with 0.3mm layer height no supports.
  • Infill 10% rectangular.
  • Top bottom 3 layers with rectangular infill.
  • Once printed you can slice out the supports inside the slot where the blower is inserted.
  • Attach to the lower side of your hotend fan with M3x25 bolts and nuts.
  • Press fit your 50mm blower fan into the designed slot.(the slot may need some cleanup) It should hold without glue, but if you want it can be used.

Printer:

FLSUN Cube

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

10%

Clip-connector.stl x2
Stand-legs.stl x2
ClipSet.stl x2
Stand-small_part_deposit.stl

title: JAL- Treadmill safety key and clothing clip for Proform C42 model PCTL2932.0

description.text:
I recently purchased a used Proform C42 treadmill model PCTL2932.0 which did not come with the safety key needed to run it, so I made this one.

I also made a clip to attach to my clothing while using the treadmill, and connected it to the key via a string. With this, if i fall or otherwise leave the treadmill during use, the safety key will be removed from the treadmill bringing it to a stop.

comments.text: Thanks! I made this and it's working perfectly for a Pro Form 750 CS I picked up off the street. Only thing I've had to buy to get it working is some belt lubricant now!

feel free to remix. Its a bit of a long print and uses some plastic. I needed it to be structurally substantial not just a spacer.

Having all 4 hole connected made installing it a lot easier than if you have for separate tubes.

4 Fillet inside corners and outside corners 10 mm fillets.

description.text:
Many fidget spinners use bearings for weights, but even cheap bearings cost 50 cents. I know many of us started designing around Nuts but there are still many design that use bearings. I made a container that holds 3 pennies and fits into the bearing slots. Now you can spend a little plastic + 3 cents and the weight is very close.

These are designed for PLA shrinkage. Other materials may shrink more or less causing them to be too tight or too loose.

title: Lamp Base for Crinkle Lamp
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is my lamp base for the popular Crinkle Lamp (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:676350)

I printed the lamp and though it needs a base. Only if I could make one hmmmmm......

For the LEDs.

I had just finished adding a lot of LEDs to my PC and under mydesk. I had a lot laying around and this seemed like a good use for them. My soldering skills are not the best.

this are basic 5050 LEDs from Amazon. you can get a kit with a 16ft roll of them for less than $20. I went to Home depot and they had in the bulk section a wire with 4 individual leads in it. that cost <$3. then I broke out the old soldering kit.

I did my soldering right there on the base but if I was to do it again I would find a more heat proof surface. As I think of it probably the glass bed from my printer or a cookie sheet. I hot glued everything after I got all of the connections running.

I can kind of see the individual LEDs through the shade but I think that is an OK trade off for not recessing the led bed and having to use supports.

If I was to do it again. I would redesign the base with a cylinder (rounded square) recess and ring the the LEDs that way. 10mm deep and stand the LEDs on end So I only have to make one connection or maybe none.

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

20 - 30 %

Notes:

Although I with I had printer it wit more infill and or thicker walls. It is very light and the wire I chose pushes it around a lot. Might double stick tape it down.

I though I wanted it to be simple and take away form the lamp shade. Simple cube centered around the X and Y axis. extruded. 4 more equal cubes inset from the corners a bit.

I chamfer the feet on the inside. I just sketched an upside down trapezoid between the feet with an angle that looked nice to me. and did a pocket or cut.

then i measure my actual lamp share i printer and inset a channel for it to sit in. It prints feet up. and the channel is so small my printer bridges it fine.
