A water dish suitable for cats and other small animals based on Simply brand juice bottle.  
READ INSTRUCTIONS BEFORE PRINTING!

This is based on the Simply Threads +2 model.  What that means is the threads print correctly with Makerware software.  They may be too loose with other software.  You may want to print a Simply Threads test before printing this thing.  
Also, this is technically a smidge too big for makerbot.  You may have a little cleanup on the front and back of the rim.  It works though, so DO NOT let it to scale to fit the build platform!  If you do it'll ruin the threads!  
Finally, I printed with makerware "low" preset.  Even at that it takes quite awhile.
This is a part for a retractable power cord reel. Im not exactly sure which model i will post in the near future.

title: BMO Shaped case for Raspberry Pi 1 B

description.text:
3D Printed case for Raspberry Pi 1 B+ (or 1B).

working video: https://youtu.be/n1TOkIIqKnI

Working on a case w/ same shape but for Raspberry Pi 2 or 3.

I started this project just to make a nice case for my Raspberry pi 1B+ I already have. I used to used Pi for KODI machine for my small old TV. But while making the case, I decided to make the Pi to have more functionalities. So add a bit more functionalities like the Sensor connection for monitoring air quality or some environmental parameters like temperature, CO2, and so on. To show them on my BMO raspberry pi, I added the screen. (purchased from aliexpress. 3.5 inch Rear view monitor.)

To make case assembly easier, I separated main parts into 5 pieces. (and some small buttons, arms, legs, BMO letters, and guide brackets.) You can make BMO with main 5 parts and buttons if you don't make reset button and the screen on it. Screen can be replaced to a paper or an acryl panel, The way implementing it is up to you.)

I soldered 2 points on the board for reset switch and composite cable. And use 5V-12V Step-up Converter board to supply a power for a screen. (I know it could work with 5V power if I modify a board a bit. But I didn't wanna solder too much. So, I decied to use converter. You don't have to solder much if you don't want to use the screen on it.

Connecting reset switch: Basically, Raspberry pi provides reset jumper, But it is not connected by default. solder a jumper head on JP6 and add a tactile(push) switch. I recommend to use 12mm×12mm square head push button for my design. Only reset and wakeup from halt was enough for me. If you need more function like safe shutdown, refer the link below.

http://www.raspberry-pi-geek.com/Archive/2013/01/Adding-an-On-Off-switch-to-your-Raspberry-Pi

Screen: To save GPIO, i didn't use the screen using GPIO parellel connection. Instead, I chose 3.5 inch LCD screen for Car rearview monitor and connect the power, composite video signal. Many 3.5" composite screens are sold on the market. I recommend to.use the product with small controller board, like what you can see on the link:
http://sudomod.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/04/IMG_2572.jpg

Power source for the monitor: I used 5V-12V step-up converter, You can easily find it on the market. It doesn't have to be exactly same with mine. But I recommend to use the converter which support 1A. And solder a Jumper to a composite signal pin. (with or without the composite connector desoldered)

Sound: At first, I directly solder small speaker to the analogue audio output port. But the signal strength from the analogue audio port is not enough to drive the speaker to make loud enough to hear. So I decided to connect the amp in the middle. You can easily find the amp board w/ volume knob that costs $1.5ish. From the specification, impedance of the audio amp is 4ohm, but it works fine with 8ohm speaker I have. If you use raspberry pi with TV and if you don't need a sound w/ not that good quality, you can ignore it.
refer the image: http://img.dxcdn.com/productimages/sku_419649_3.jpg

Showing BMO's face during the boot procedure: My BMO shows two different faces while booting. The first one is enabled by Retropie setup menu. And I found another way to enable the splash screen at a different moment. Please see the link below. For the images of BMO's faces, you may easily find on the internet or make the images yourself. But you need to resize or change the resolution setting to make it be shown correctly. 1920x1080 is recommended for the resolution of the image to make it be shown full screen.

Recommended screws for assembling: I used two different screws to assemble BMO case and tighten the board on the bottom panel. Both are M3 screws but length of the screws are different. I used 6mm length screws to tighten the Front, Bottom, Back and Side panels. And, 4mm length screws were used for tighten Back cover on the back panel. To put the raspi board on the bottom panel, Both are Okay. I recommend you to use flat head screws to make the case look better. I used the M3 screws for Thinkpad laptop. You can easily find sellers on Amazon.com or aliexpress.com

It's still working project. I will update a bill of materials I used, add some more models for RPi 3, and sensors when they are done. If any comment or suggestion, please let me know.

title: Tripplite 20A server power strip wall clips

description.text:
I had an old Tripp-lite 6 foot tall, 20A 24 port NEMA 5-15 server power strip designed for vertical installation in server cabinets that I wanted to use for my work bench area to provide a LOT of power outlets for projects. Since I had a 120V - 20A circuit in that area, it was a good excuse to finally use it. However, vertical orientation is less than useful in a garage.

I decided to quickly build a set of wall clips that I can screw to the wall and then clip in the power strip to provide an abundance of electrical ports within easy reach. For a 6' power strip, I would recommend to print at least 4 clips and screw them in to studs along the length. I used standard 6 x 1-5/8 gold wood screws I had laying around.

Once the clips are mounted, just snap in the power strip with the edge clipping over the front.

author: iamdarkyoshi

title: Anet A8 Y-axis Rod movement and vibration elimination
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Same design as Supernova69's, but I made these shorter so if you have a front frame brace, these shouldn't interfere. The ones from Supernova69 were too long and interfered with the frame brace I have installed from:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2118713

Once printed, the hole, at least on mine, was barely too small so you have to force it on there and wiggle it around until it slides on there, but by doing so, it gives you a perfect fit and prevents the rod from moving.

UPDATE: If you are using the REAR brace from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2118713 with the threaded rods as mentioned above, you need to print 1 of the files labeled "Y-axis vibration dampener rear brace near motor" and 3 of the normal ones. It gets installed on the rod closest to the Y-axis motor as it is slightly shorter due to the brace being close to the screw.

This is an intake filter for 3/8in line running to those 8-10$ BLDC pumps on amazon/ebay. The pumps work great except they easily get clogged if they pull in anything larger than a few mm.
Had some plants die after the pump stopped but no issues since installing these.

take some bug screen from the hardware store, cut it to length 1.5 x the circumference of the filter and from the base to where the taper starts. roll it up and zip tie the top. make sure the screen pokes down into the channel running around the base.

Pump link: http://a.co/icwkEhy

This is a simple mounting solution for the Digoo DG-M1Q cheapie security camera.

The bracket hinges in one direction but allows the camera to be held securely at different rotations so you can rotate the bracket to suit your needs. The body is over-sized compared to the camera to allow the USB cable to be better hidden behind the plate.

You need 2x M3 bolts to hold the two parts together and the plate hole size should allow the M3 bolts to tighten up enough to keep whatever angle you choose. If you're really concerned, just use a bit of general purpose glue as a thread locker.

description.text:
Made this 12CM fan shroud to increase efficiency (in silly, uneducated theory) and at the very least, to help locate-to-center the wet/soaking media tower in my DIY 5-gallon-bucket swamp cooler. I have no idea whether it increases effectiveness of the evaporative cooler due to aerodynamics, since A. I don't know squat about aerodynamics and B. I haven't bothered to do any A/B testing. But it definitely helps keep the cooling tower properly located within the bucket and centered under the fan, so 100% of the air from the fan passes through the cooling media rather than blowing to the outside of the tower and straight out the exhaust vents.

Who knows, someone might find it useful. If you're making a DIY swamp cooler from a 12CM fan and a 5 gallon bucket, well, certainly I recommend it. :-)

BTW, the 12CM, 12V "Delta" fan you see in these photos is a CRAZY, CRAZY 12V fan. Highly recommended if airflow and static pressure are all that matter, and noise is a non-issue. Holy cow, I've never seen a fan so small move so much air.

print_settings.Notes:: I printed this with 100% infill and 6 perimeters to make it as solid as possible. This also helps the M4 screws securely mount the bracket to the block.

description.text:
I wanted to use the aluminum stepper motor mount rather than the printed one supplied in the printer files.

Here is the mount I used and this is a mounting block for this extruder motor mount, which offers a very stable arm to make it easier to change filament, along with a better grip on the filament since it does not use a flat bearing.

You will need 4 of the 10mm M5 screws washers and square nuts to secure the mount to the frame. The screw holes to mount the bracket are for M4 screws. I do not know the exact size I used but it is designed to fit up to 25mm long screws.

NOTE: This should be printed in the orientation pictured.

The screw holes to secure it to the frame are supposed to be covered, this way (just like the D-Bot parts) you do not need to print this with supports.

print_settings.Notes:: Use ABS

description.text:
When you buy an Intex pool, it's coming with a small pump and hoses, generally too small for the pool volume : you have to buy a bigger pump with sand filter, generally sold with only ONE hose adaptor.
This thing allow you to print the missing 2.

I did not designed the place for the o-ring seal for several reasons :
-you cannot print it and it's difficult to find
-the groove make the part weaker
-you don't need it if you put some teflon tape on the printed part before putting the hose

WARNING : I did 2 separate designs for 32mm and 38mm diameter hoses, the original adaptors have the 2 in 1 but is too long and can be too weak once printed. Choose the good one adapted to your hoses.

Quand vous achetez une piscine Intex, elle est livrée avec une petite pompe généralement trop petite pour le volume de la piscine : vous finissez par acheter une plus grosse pompe avec filtre à sable, qui est livrée avec un seul adaptateur pour les tuyaux (oui, c'est complètement débile, mais faut demander à Intex ;-))
Voilà de quoi imprimer les 2 adaptateurs manquants.
Je n'ai pas mis de gorge pour le joint torique pour plusieurs raisons :
-on ne peut pas imprimer ce joint et il peut être aussi difficile à trouver que les adaptateurs
-la gorge fragilise l'objet
-on n'a pas besoin de joint si on met du scotch teflon sur l'embout avant d'emmancher le tuyau.

ATTENTION : j'ai fait 2 design séparés pour les tuyaux de diamètre 32mm et de 38mm, les adaptateurs d'origine ont les 2 en 1, mais sont trop longs et donc trop fragiles une fois imprimés. choisissez celui qui va bien avec vos tuyaux !

author: SteveAtShipley

description.text:
Simple multipurpose general LED light

What?

My wife needed a light for her keyboard so she could read the sheet music. Instead of buying one I decided to design and build one of my own. Then I figured why it couldn't be more generic? With long neck it would be really useful in countless situations. As time passed the more ideas for usage popped up. The video contains only a few of them.

Usage

This thing can be used for lighting innumerable places: reading sheet music, fixing cars, searching keys in the dark, spare light during power cut, reading light and many many other places, you name it. With long adjustable neck it can bring light places where normal flashlights can't go.

Building it

Besides all the printed parts you will need:

  • Screws with size M3 and variable lengths between 12mm to 30mm. Tip: Use nyloc nuts where ever possible.
  • Red and black wires
  • An on/off switch
  • Double AAA battery box
  • Two AAA batteries
  • LED (OSM5XME1E1E)

Steps:

  1. Print Base.stl and Lid.stl files
  2. Print as many LightShade.stl and LightShadeLid_xxx_mm.stl files as you need. The xxx in the file name means the tolerance of the lid fasteners against the light shade. I used 0.5 mm tolerance.
  3. Print as many BeamsWithWireLoops.stl as you think you'll need.
  4. Cut some black (-) and red (+) wires as long as you think you'll need. And some extra ;)
  5. Solder the wires to an LED.
  6. Thread the wires through the LightShade.stl and BeamsWithWireLoops.stl
  7. Snap the LightShadeLid.stl on top of LightShade.stl. If it's loose, print another one with smaller tolerance or just glue them together (I had to glue them once).
  8. Solder the red wire to an on/off switch
  9. Solder a new red wire to an on/off switch
  10. Solder the new red wire and the black wire to an AAA battery box.
  11. Glue the AAA battery box in the bottom of the base.
  12. Attach the on/off switch to the side of the base.
  13. (Optional) Print as many BalkCorner.stl, BarFastener.stl, Beams.stl, Hook.stl, TriBeam.stl and/or WallFastener.stl files as you like/need.
  14. Put the batteries
  15. Screw all the parts together in the form as you like/need.
  16. Take a pic and upload it to the Thingiverse after clicking "I made one" on this page

Videos and links

Introduction video:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sIBE2rlNVvc

See also automatic closet light version of this thing:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2412201

See also glasses light version of this thing:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2441115

I know, I could do it myself, but I like if others are working for me ;-)

title: Very thin iPhone 7 case with tactile feel - Flower of Life design
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is a thin iPhone 7 case, designed completely from ground up using Apple's case specifications, It has the same curve and corner rounding of the phone itself.

if you are looking for an iPhone 6/6s case see thing here https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1813164

The tolerance are tight, it is a trade-off between tight fitting, but just flexible enough to snap over the phone. It was designed for rigid filaments,

This is a very slim design, which is my personal preference, but such that it still can can be put face down without scratching the screen.

I've made several organic patterns, but posted the Flower of Life here.

For printing I have added anti-warp discs, just snap then off, and maybe smooth any sharp points with a lighter. Any form of warping will prevent the phone from fitting properly. After printing clean any residue or whatever from the inside curve, any blobs will also prevent the phone from fitting properly.

I printed at 0.2mm layer and at 50-100% infill..

Please note the license, it is for personal use only, with no commercialization

title: Customizable Sanding Stick
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I like the idea of the Sanding stick by workshopbob, but I don't want to buy some hex screws. So I've created this thing, where you can customize your sanding stick, that will automatically include the needed printable screws.

I have also added the four sticks I'm using in the first picture as .stl files.

Attribution: I used the Sanding stick of workshopbob, licensed under the Creative Commons - Attribution license, as an inspiration for my Customizable Sanding Stick.

Customizable Settings

  • set the length, height and width (picture 3)
  • 3 different end styles: none, round and wedge (picture 4)
  • set the angle and a smooth round end for wedge style

Customizable Sanding Stick on YouTube

RCLifeOn: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eK8k_6zu0hs
Print 3D Channel: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kY7AoZirRsI

Changelog

v1.3 - 2017-08-08:

  • [feature] parts will be generated in separate stl-Files additionally.

v1.2 - 2017-07-31:

  • [fix] reduced the tolerance of the threaded hole. If you have problems, to insert the screw in, you can change the tolerance in the screw-settings-advanced section -> Screw Thread Hole Dia In Millimeter.
  • [feature] parameter to add extra height of the screws head

v1.1 - 2017-06-27:

  • [feature] added color
  • [cosmetic] updated description for screw settings

How to support me?

Do you like my things and do you want to support me? You can use these links if you want to buy something. This helps me doing more things. Thanks!

Banggood: https://goo.gl/ZXgx3A
Gearbest: https://goo.gl/FfE59f
Aliexpress: https://goo.gl/bQLi15

Printer:

Anet A8

Resolution:

0.2 or better

Infill:

50%

Notes:

You can use lower infill, as long as the infill is present in each layer of the screw. Or you can use separate infill settings for each part e.g. 50% for bottom part and screws, 25% for top part. You can easily separate the part in Simplify3D under Mesh -> Separate Connected Surfaces. You can also separate the parts in the customizer.

Step 1

Cut a strip of a sheet of sanding paper in the width of the stick. The length should be about the hole around the stick to the second hole + a little extra length.

Step 2

Wrap the strip around the stick from the edge of the first hole beginning to the edge of the second hole. You may cut the length in this step. You can either use your fingers or the top part to hold the strip in place.

Step 3

Screw the first screw in. Then you can tension the strip, lift the top part a bit and push the end of the strip between the top and bottom part. Use the second screw now.
Optional: You can use pliers to tighten the screws, but don't overtighten it!

Website

https://mightynozzle.com

comments.author: Dranoweb

comments.text: Actually as an idle thought I have just had regarding the license that thingiverse use - it is fairly heavily oriented around a single finished product, and is somewhat more vague regarding customized items. it's a bit of a grey area in terms of the thingiverse license terminology, when a 3rd party contributes some or all of the parameters required to create the object, EG: it's not specific at what point or percentage an item ceases to be the property of the copyright holder.
comments.author: mightynozzle

comments.text: That's an interesting thought. I think that depends on the quantity of settings and how much the result of the custom thing differs from the original or default thing. But it isn't easy to measure. Or maybe the time was needed to create the thing? Designing, programming and testing this thing took me some weeks. Creating a derivate of this thing via Customizer, take some minutes. I don't know. On the other hand, the share-alike term could solve this problem. All remixes needs to share with the same license and its terms.
comments.author: Dranoweb

title: Raspberry Pi case for Adafruits 16x2 LCD + Keypad
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I picked up a 16x2 LCD + Keypad kit from Adafruit, and wanted a nice case for it. The top piece I modeled to slip over the bottom. The bottom is the excellent design from from the Raspberry Pi Case thing. The download for the bottom I've included here is the same thing as found on that page. Visit my blog for a tutorial on how to build a Raspberry FM player of your own.
See it in action on Youtube.

Printed in 1hr 22min using "low" on my Replicator1, using modified low settings in Makerware:
Light Blue PLA
Extruded @ 220
HPB Off, Blue painters tape on glass.
2 shells, 5% infill

title: Ultimate Electronics Helper - Bench PSU with Helping Hands

description.text:
How it's made: https://youtu.be/V5kF0q1VqE4
https://www.instructables.com/id/Ultimate-Electronics-Helper-Variable-Bench-Top-PSU

All parts are made with nice margins so everything should fit together easily. This also means you have room for several different power supplies and electronics if you want to switch out anything later on.

I printed everything except the helping hands adapters at 0.3 mm which was the roughest resolution on my printer. The adapters were printed at 0.1 mm. All in all it took about seven hours printing everything in PLA and 5% infill for strength.

description.text:
Mounts a Profile Design Aqualite aero bottle to Profile Design T2+ DL aluminum aerobars. This setup allows you to drink on a ride without reaching for a separate bottle down below. It keeps you
focused on the road and drinking more often during the bike leg of a triathlon.

Simple one-piece design. Rock solid mounting using the Velcro strap that comes with the bottle.
Snaps firmly on the bars. Much less complicated and more solid than the Profile Designs multi-part
adjustable bottle mount.

Works with other aluminum aerobars with 22mm diameter. spacing between bars 106mm
center-to-center. Recommend attaching the clip to the bars when you install them on your bike to
ensure the spacing is correct.

Also includes zip tie holes to more permanently attach if needed.

Triathlete? Check out my Triathlon Bike Number Mount too.

Printer:

Da Vinci 1.0A hacked with E3D-v6 and Repetier V92

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm layers

Infill:

Solid works best

Notes:

Works best in ABS. Print is in Atomic brand black ABS - great material!

Prints well without supports standing on the back surface. 102g.

If you print and use, please consider posting a picture in the Make section. I'd love to see your setup. Thanks. Matt
